verses.text: Paul, an apostle—not sent from men nor by a man, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised Him from the dead—
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes his apostolic authority comes directly from Christ and the Father, distinguishing it from human appointment. The reference to Christ's resurrection underlines the heart of the Gospel. The phrase 'not from men nor by a man' subtly points to divinely appointed leadership.

verses.text: and all the brothers with me, to the churches of Galatia:
verses.comment: Paul includes fellow believers, signaling unity and communal support. 'Churches' shows the early Christian community was organized and connected.

verses.text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.comment: This traditional blessing highlights the co-equality of the Father and the Son, supporting the doctrine of the Trinity (see John 1:1-2).

verses.text: who gave Himself for our sins, to deliver us out of the present evil age, according to the will of our God and Father,
verses.comment: Christ's self-offering fulfills prophecy (Isaiah 53). Salvation is described as rescue from evil, according to the Father's will, reflecting both a spiritual and literal understanding of redemption.

verses.text: to whom be the glory forever and ever. Amen.
verses.comment: Paul closes his greeting with doxology, giving eternal glory to God. The early Christian communities often used such formulas in their liturgical prayers.

verses.text: I am amazed that you are so quickly turning from Him who called you by the grace of Christ to a different gospel,
verses.comment: Paul’s astonishment signals the importance of remaining steadfast in the true Gospel.

verses.text: which is really not another; but there are some who trouble you and want to distort the gospel of Christ.
verses.comment: There is only one true Gospel; those who try to alter it introduce confusion and division, echoing the warnings against false teachers in the New Testament.

verses.text: But even if we, or an angel from heaven, should preach any gospel to you other than what we preached to you, let him be accursed.
verses.comment: Paul's strong language reveals the unchangeable nature of the apostolic teaching—binding on all, even supernatural messengers. This undergirds the need for authoritative interpretation by those chosen by God.

verses.text: As we have said before, so I now say again: If anyone is preaching to you a gospel contrary to what you received, let him be accursed.
verses.comment: Repetition underscores Paul's seriousness and hints at the authority and permanence of the original message handed down.

verses.text: For am I now seeking the favor of men, or of God? Or am I trying to please men? If I were still pleasing men, I would not be a servant of Christ.
verses.comment: Servanthood to Christ demands loyalty to divine truth over human opinion or approval.

verses.text: For I make known to you, brothers, that the gospel I proclaimed is not according to man.
verses.comment: Paul reiterates the divine origin of his message, not a human invention but revealed from above.

verses.text: For I did not receive it from man, nor was I taught it, but it came through a revelation of Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The Gospel is revealed by Christ Himself, not simple tradition or teaching—a foundation for spiritual authority in the Church.

verses.text: For you have heard of my former way of life in Judaism, how I severely persecuted the church of God and tried to destroy it.
verses.comment: Paul's conversion from persecutor to apostle affirms the transformative power of divine grace and calling.

verses.text: And I was advancing in Judaism beyond many of my age, being extremely zealous for the traditions of my fathers.
verses.comment: Paul's zeal for tradition highlights the need for grace to surpass human effort and religious practice.

verses.text: But when He who set me apart from my mother’s womb and called me by His grace was pleased
verses.comment: God's foreknowledge and choosing, even before birth, echoes the prophetic tradition. The language of 'calling' anticipates a view of vocation that is both divine and personal.

verses.text: to reveal His Son in me, so that I might preach Him among the nations, I did not consult with flesh and blood;
verses.comment: God's initiative in revealing Christ and the universal mission reflects a continuity with the plan of salvation for all peoples. 'Not consulting flesh and blood' points to supernatural guidance.

verses.text: nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me, but I went away to Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.
verses.comment: Paul’s independent journey after conversion emphasizes his authority from Christ, yet connects to established leadership when the time is right.

verses.text: Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to become acquainted with Cephas, and stayed with him fifteen days.
verses.comment: Meeting Cephas (Peter) after several years suggests a process of recognition and confirmation among leaders. The prominence of Peter as the chief apostle is subtly present here.

verses.text: But I saw none of the other apostles except James, the Lord’s brother.
verses.comment: James's role as a leader in the Jerusalem church becomes apparent, highlighting early hierarchical structures.

verses.text: Now about the things I am writing to you, before God, I am not lying.
verses.comment: Paul testifies to his honesty under oath, strengthening the trust in apostolic witness.

verses.text: Then I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.
verses.comment: Paul's missionary journeys illustrate the spread and universality of the Gospel. His travels foreshadow the global reach and unity of the Church.

verses.text: And I was still unknown by face to the churches of Judea which are in Christ.
verses.comment: The Judean churches existed as distinct local communities united in Christ, suggesting an organized body even early in Christian history.

verses.text: But they only kept hearing, ‘He who once persecuted us is now preaching the faith he once tried to destroy.’
verses.comment: Paul's example is a powerful testimony of conversion and mission, demonstrating the Gospel’s power to transform individuals for the service of the Church.

verses.text: And they glorified God because of me.
verses.comment: The believers' reaction, glorifying God, shows that transformation through grace leads not only to personal change but also communal praise—integral to Christian worship and communal life.
